metadata.title: Supplementary appendix Supplemental Appendix -Lancet Seminar Title: Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS)

body_text.text: Structural studies showed that the receptor binding domain (RBD) of the S protein is highly flexible and present in two conformations, only one of which was exposed and predicted to bind to the host cell receptor. After binding to receptor, two proteolytic events are required prior to fusion of viral and host cell membranes, which results in cell entry. 1 The S protein is the principal target for the neutralizing antibody response. Some neutralizing antibodies not only block entry but trigger premature maturation and subsequent inactivation of the S protein. 2 Additionally, the S protein exhibits low affinity binding to glycans, which is important for infectivity and may function by juxtaposing cellular and viral membranes prior to receptor binding. 3 The first two thirds of genomic RNA encodes a large polyprotein (rep1a/b), which is then cleaved into 16 individual proteins, many of which are required for replication and transcription. Three of these non-structural proteins, nsp3, nsp4 and nsp6 induce membrane rearrangements, including double membrane vesicles (DMV), to facilitate the formation of replication-transcription complexes (RTC) on which RNA synthesis actually occurs. 4, 5 Nonstructural proteins (nsp) inhibit host gene expression by inhibiting host mRNA translation and inducing the degradation of host mRNAs (nsp1), and by inhibiting interferon- (IFN-I) induction (nsp3, nsp15, nsp16). [6] [7] [8] [9] These serve as targets for
anti-viral therapy development (Figure 1 in main manuscript).

RTC formation uses host cell machinery involved in vesicular transport of misfolded proteins. 10 RNA transcription occurs from 7 subgenomic mRNAs, which are 3' co-terminally nested (hence the name 'nidovirus') and contain a common 5' leader sequence derived from genomic RNA. 13 These subgenomic RNAs encode structural proteins, which are found in all CoV, and accessory proteins that have immune-evasive and perhaps other functions. These accessory proteins are unique to each
CoV and with rare exceptions, share homology with no other viral or host proteins. MERS-CoV encodes 5 accessory proteins (ORFs 3, 4a, 4b and 5, and 8b, which is embedded within the N gene).

These accessory proteins were shown to interfere with IFN induction or signaling, or NF-kB signaling although many of these observations were made using proteins expressed in the absence of virus infection. 14-17 ORFs 3-5 are variably deleted from camel and human isolates of MERS-CoV without clear changes in virulence. [18] [19] [20] These results together do not support an essential role for these accessory proteins in human or camel MERS-CoV infections but rather raise the possibility that their function is most important for virus virulence in specific hosts or settings. 22 In marked contrast, while mutations in MERS-CoV have been detected in human isolates since 2012, these are, with rare exceptions, not fixed into the viral genome. 23 Rather changes in human isolates appear to reflect transmission of variants first detected in camel populations. 24 Remarkably, MERS-CoV isolates with reduced affinity for the human DPP4 receptor were detected as the Korean MERS outbreak progressed. 25, 26 This was unexpected because increased receptor affinity is predicted to emerge and enhance virulence, as occurred during the SARS epidemic in which affinity for the host cell receptor, angiotensinconverting enzyme 2 increased with time. Virus with decreased affinity for the receptor appeared to be equivalent to the parental strain in virulence and transmission, suggesting that factors other than receptor binding, such as susceptibility to proteases required for S protein processing, are relatively more important in MERS-CoV cellular entry. 1, 27 Epidemiology

While MERS-CoV has been circulating in dromedary camel populations in Africa and the Arabian Peninsula for at least several decades, 28 the emergence of MERS-CoV as a novel human pathogen has been estimated as mid-2011. 29 32 MERS-CoV has been identified in dromedary camels in a several countries across Africa, the Middle East and South Asia ( Figure S1 ) 33, 34 and to a much lesser extent in sheep in Senegal, Tunisia and Egypt. 35 Serological evidence of MERS-CoV in dromedaries has been found in 20 countries, with molecular evidence for MERS-CoV circulation in 13 countries. 33, 34 Experimental infections have shown that infected dromedaries shed MERS-CoV from their nasal secretions with minimal signs of illness, which is limited to rhinorrhea. 34

Up to half of the primary human MERS-CoV cases report a history of exposure to dromedary camels and one third of all community MERS cases report contact with camels. 38, 52, 53 Although dromedary camels are an important source of MERS-CoV-mediated human infection and disease, the exact mode(s) of transmission are not well understood since approximately half primary MERS cases do not report a history of camel exposure ( Figure S1 ). 34, 38, [54] [55] [56]
Limited human-to-human transmission is well documented from household, community and hospital outbreaks. 23

Several experimentally infected animal models for MERS have been developed, although it is recognized that none of these animals develop the protracted virus replication and pathological outcomes observed in humans. Non-human primates, rabbits and dromedary camels can be infected by MERS-CoV, but with the possible exceptions of marmosets, these animals develop mild pneumonia, or in the case of camels, rhinitis. 36
Chest X-Rays: Examples of chest-X-Ray findings from MERS patients and progression over the course of illness are shown in Figures S2a-S2e .

The intensity of clinical morbidity may not correlate with imaging abnormalities. Radiographic progression from unilateral focal air-space opacity to either multi-focal or bilateral involvement during the second phase of the disease, followed by radiographic improvement with treatment, is commonly observed. A scoring system for chest X-rays developed during the Korean MERS outbreak indicated that MERS patients with radiographic score >10 on day 10 from viral exposure may require aggressive intensive therapy with careful surveillance and follow-up evaluation. 85 CT scans: During the early phase of the disease, lung parenchymal abnormalities are typically located in the peripheral lower lobes; from there, they eventually spread to the entire bilateral lungs at the advanced stage (Figure 4b) . Whilst CT is more sensitive and specific than chest radiography, the high rate of underlying comorbidities in patients with MERS-CoV may create considerable difficulty in detecting disease progression due to overlapping preexisting comorbidities, such as lung fibrosis or emphysema or infectious complications.

The prevention of transmission of MERS-CoV in the community and in healthcare settings is critical to preventing outbreaks and further spread. Several substantive reviews and WHO guidelines are available on the subject. 52,88-90

Efforts to reduce the risk of transmission of MERS-CoV to humans should focus on the potential roles of camel markets, camel races, importation, transportation and grazing in amplification and shedding of the virus, providing a basis for evidence-based control approaches.

Early identification and isolation of suspected or confirmed cases and ongoing surveillance are key to preventing nosocomial spread. 91 or mutation of proteins essential for virulence but not virus replication. 14, 93, 94 For example, virus mutated in nsp14, which is required for genome fidelity, replicates well but is highly attenuated. 95 Many of these vaccines have been tested in animals experimentally infected with MERS-CoV, including mice expressing the hDPP4 receptor and nonhuman primates. Several were in, or are currently undergoing in Phase I trials, in which safety and immunogenicity are examined in healthy adults. In one instance, healthy adults aged between 18-50 years were vaccinated three times with a DNA vaccine (GLS-5300) expressing a full-length consensus MERS-CoV S protein. 96 Immunoconversion as measured by S1-ELISA, neutralizing antibody and T cell responses were 94%, 43% and 76% of subjects, respectively although these all declined by 60 weeks after immunization. The vaccine was well tolerated with only mild adverse effects. The adverse effects associated with this DNA vaccine (delivered by IM electroporation) were partly ameliorated by intradermal delivery.

Studies of immunogenicity are in progress. These encouraging results need to be advanced quickly in phase 2 trials with adequate numbers of subjects including elderly and co-morbid populations, to evaluate effective protective long lasting immune responses, mitigating future outbreaks and alleviating disease burden from the most vulnerable populations -the elderly, the immunosuppressed, and healthcare workers. 97 In other approaches, camels were immunized with an S protein subunit vaccine 98 One-Health approach to tackling MERS:

The One Health concept focuses on the relationship and interconnectedness between humans, animals and the environment, and recognizes that the health and wellbeing of humans is intimately . FIGREF0.text: ,52,57-6566 MERS-CoV has been identified in sputum, nasal or nasopharyngeal samples, endotracheal aspirates, bronchoalveolar lavages, urine, faeces, blood and lung tissue.52,60 Personto-person spread of MERS-CoV most likely occurs through unprotected direct or indirect contact, airborne transmission when aerosol-generating procedures are performed, although the exact mechanism of transmission require further investigation. 32,52 A study of 280 household contacts of 26 index MERS-CoV-infected KSA patients, with follow-up serologic analysis in 44 contacts determined the rate of subclinical secondary infection after exposure to primary cases. 62 Twelve probable cases of secondary transmission, and seven apparently healthy household contacts were MERS-CoV positive in their upper respiratory tract. 62 A study of 79 extended family members after an MERS-CoV outbreak in KSA in 2014, found that 19 (24%) were MERS-CoV positive; 11 were seriously ill and hospitalized, and 2 died. 67 Risk factors identified by the study for household transmission were: handling patient's excreta and respiratory secretions and sleeping in the index patient's room. Low levels of MERS-CoV RNA have been reported from asymptomatic subjects from MERS-CoV outbreaks in a Jeddah hospital after exposure to infected patients. 68 Risk factors for infection among 19 cases identified during a MERS outbreak in an all-female dormitory Riyadh in 2015 were direct contact or sharing a room with a known case. 63Nosocomial transmission of MERS-CoV:An analysis of eleven healthcare-associated outbreaks in KSA and the Republic of Korea between 2015-2017 found twenty-five percent (n=105/422) of MERS cases who acquired nosocomial infection were healthcare personnel.69 The study highlighted heterogeneities in the epidemiological profile and reproduction number (ranging from 1.0-5.7) at the start of healthcare associated outbreaks.These studies emphasize the need for standardized data collection to better understand the natural history of asymptomatic infections, and the role of mildly symptomatic HCWs in MERS-CoV nosocomial transmission, and to obtain detailed information on the specific interventions used and their impact during nosocomial outbreaks.Over the past three years, efforts from affected member states especially in health care facilities have led to improvements in implementation of standard and enhanced infection control measures, resulting in a decrease in the number of secondary cases resulting from human-to-human transmission in health care facilities.70

FIGREF1.text: Pleural effusion is relatively rare in cases of MERS and the presence of pleural effusion in patients is a poor prognostic indicator. In the 2015 South Korean outbreak, 68% (123/180) of patients on admission had abnormal chest radiographs, while 80.8% (147/182) developed abnormalities during the course of the disease. Abrupt progression of pneumonia occurred around day 7 of illness.86 Systematic quantitative evaluation of sequential chest radiographs in severely ill patients in the ICU can be used to predict a poor prognosis and higher mortality in MERS-CoV patients.87

FIGREF2.text: Droplet precaution (wearing a surgical mask within 1 m of the patient) and contact and droplet precautions (wearing gown, gloves, mask, eye protection on entering the room and removing them on leaving) are essential when caring for patients with suspected MERS. Healthcare workers (HCWs) should implement airborne precautions and wear a fittested particulate respirator such as a US NIOSH-approved N95 filtering facepiece respirator (FFR) or a European EN-approved FFP2 or FFP3 filtering facepiece respirator) when performing aerosolgenerating procedures for infected and potentially-infected patients. To reduce room contamination in the hospital setting, the application of a minimum room ventilation rate of 12 air changes per hour in a single room or or at least 160 litres/second/patient in facilities with natural ventilation is recommended when caring for patients receiving mechanical ventilation and during aerosol-generating procedures. Avoiding aerosolizing procedures in crowded hospital emergency or inpatient medical wards without adequate control measures have been recommended to decrease risk MERS-CoV human-to-human spread and environmental contamination. 52 When recognition of a nosocomial outbreak of MERS-CoV is delayed, hospital closure for any new admissions and preventing transfers to other hospitals have been utilized when available resources to contain the outbreak have been overwhelmed. Advances in MERS vaccine development: A variety of vectored vaccines based on measles virus, chimpanzee adenovirus, rabies virus and modified vaccinia virus have been developed and some are undergoing clinical trials. 92 ,(https://clinicaltrials.gov/) Development of live attenuated vaccines is guided by our understanding of the details of virus replication and of virus-host interactions. Some vaccines are based on deletion

FIGREF3.text: connected to the health of animals and their environment (and vice versa). MERS offers unique opportunities for all stakeholders involved in human and animal health systems to take forward a 'One Health' approach to control such zoonotic pathogens with epidemic potential. These includeidentifying animal and environmental factors behind the emergence and sustainability of MERS-CoV in certain regions, identification of the exact mechanism of transmission of MERS-CoV from camels to humans and searching for new reservoir(s). 32,101-103 Critical to the establishment of 'One Health' platform consortia is the creation of multidisciplinary teams with a range of expertise including public health officers, physicians, veterinarians, animal husbandry specialists, agriculturalists, ecologists, vector biologists, viral phylogeneticists, and researchers to co-operate, collaborate to learn more about zoonotic spread between animals, humans and the environment and to monitor, respond to and prevent major outbreaks. TABREF1.text: In addition to encoding the viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), helicase and related proteins, other ORF1 proteins are involved in formation of the cap structure found at the 5' end of viral RNAs. The absence of the final step in capping, 2'-O methylation, performed by nsp16, renders viral RNA sensitive to detection by cellular helical sensors, especially MDA5.9 A second protein, nsp3, is multifunctional and in addition to a role in assembly of RTC complexes, has protease activity, required for processing of the viral protein and encodes a macrodomain, which counters host antiviral enzymes that ADP ribosylate host proteins.11,12 At present, it is not known which proteins undergo ADP ribosylation, but knowledge of these targets may be useful in developmentof anti-MERS-CoV therapy. Once virion RNA has been replicated, it is encapsidated by the nucleocapsid (N) protein and transported from the RTC to the endoplasmic reticulum-Golgi intermediate compartment (ERGIC), where viral assembly occurs. After budding into a lipid membrane that contains the S, M, E proteins, virus is released from cells.

TABREF2.text: exonuclease, ExoN in nsp14.21 Nsp14 has RNA proofreading activities, which is essential for genome fidelity during replication of the large CoV RNA genome. CoV and other nidoviruses are the only known RNA viruses that encode such an enzyme and, in its absence, the error rate exhibited by the RNA polymerase results in virus attenuation. The role of the high rate of mutation in virus evolution

TABREF3.text: A phylogenetic study hypothesizes that bats may be the evolutionary source of MERS-CoV and MERS-related CoV have been identified from a Neoromicia capensis bat in South Africa 29,30 although no conclusive epidemiological links have been made to date. Zoonotic transmission to humans may require an incidental amplifying in intermediate hosts apart from camels. 31 Surveillance efforts have searched for evidence of MERS-CoV infection in other domestic and wild animal species.

TABREF4.text: However, African MERS-CoV lineages have not appeared to establish themselves in camels in KSA 18 , pointing toward potential differences in transmission dynamics and selection pressure. Epidemiological links between MERS-CoV-infected dromedaries and human MERS cases have been identified in several studies. 23,34,38-42 Viral RNA sequencing of samples from infected dromedary camels confirmed camel-to-human transmission of MERS-CoV and have identified identical or nearly identical MERS-CoV genomes. 43-47 The spillover from dromedary camels to humans is now well documented in the Arabian Peninsula, 43,48,49 but the extent to which spillover is occurring in countries outside the Arabian Peninsula remains unclear. Recent research evaluating the extent of MERS-CoV infection in areas with high concentrations of infected dromedaries 33,34 has found variable evidence of MERS-CoV infection in high risk occupationally exposed persons 50,51 and efforts to better characterize MERS-CoV genetic sequences across Africa, the Middle East and South Asia are currently underway. 18,35 WHO is supporting molecular and serological studies at the dromedary-human interface in several countries in Africa and South Asia. 32

TABREF5.text: Rodents are naturally resistant to MERS-CoV but become susceptible after provision of exogenous hDPP4. hDPP4 can be delivered by transduction with an adenovirus expressing hDD4, by transgenic expression or by replacement of the mouse DPP4 with hDPP4 (hDPP4-KI).[79][80][81][82][83] Transgenic mice that express hDPP4 develop encephalitis as well as lung disease, limiting their utility.84 In contrast, infection of hDPP4-KI mice with human strains of MERS-CoV causes subclinical disease with virus replication limited to the lungs. However, adaptation by serial passage through the lungs of mice resulted in the selection of a virus that is highly virulent in hDPP4-KI mice.81,82 hDPP4-KI mice are useful for studies of MERS pathogenesis and for evaluation of vaccines and antiviral therapies.

TABREF6.text: or a camelpox virus expressing the S protein99 , since juvenile camels are the primary zoonotic source for infection.Camel antibody responses to camelpox and to MERS-CoV were detected at 4 weeks after cowpox vaccination and mostly protected camels from rhinitis after virus challenge. In general, these studies demonstrate the feasibility of developing vaccines for camels or humans that elicited robust antibody responses, and in some cases, T cell responses. Vaccine development requires carefully monitoring for adverse side effects. For example, an inactivated whole MERS-CoV vaccine induced lung immunopathological changes after challenge, suggestive of a hypersensitivity reaction.100
